blogPost.title: ELTV: Human Resource in the Profit Column
blogPost.content:
Intangible capital such as knowledge and human talent form a significant chunk of a company’s valuation. This has led to companies viewing their employees as value creators rather than cost. Today, employees are added to the profit column in the balance sheet. How do you determine the financial contribution of a given employee?

The answer: Employee Lifetime Value (ELTV).

ELTV measures the long-term financial contribution of employees, similar to Customer Lifetime Value. It evaluates the net contribution by an employee considering both tangible and intangible contributions the employee makes to an organization. With data science and tools that use artificial intelligence in HR, employee behavior and contribution, both qualitative and quantitative, are measurable. This makes the evaluation process objective, removing all subjectivity in the current performance evaluation process.

Using ELTV, HR could determine what kind of investment the company should make in the long and short term to bring out the best in the employee. It helps managers focus on outcome and productivity. Managers could determine the right investment needed to maximize performance in the long run. It also helps in sprucing up income generating behavior of an employee.

For the HR function, this would enhance the strategic value of the function manifold allowing them to play a key role in the company’s investment decisions and financial performance.
